title: Starmer to set date to increase defence spending during Trump visit – report
body:
Sir Keir Starmer is expected to confirm a timeline to raise defence spending and give Donald Trump an invitation for a state visit when he visits Washington next week, according to a report.

The Prime Minister will have to walk a tricky line when he meets Mr Trump, balancing the UK's support for Ukraine with the need to keep the US onside.

The US president has started negotiations with Russia on ending the conflict, but excluded Kyiv from the talks – and a deepening rift has emerged between him and Ukrainian president Volodymyr Zelensky as the two have traded barbs.

Washington has also put pressure on the UK and its allies to do more to shoulder the burden of European defence.

The late Queen and Donald Trump Credit: Chris Jackson/PA

In an effort to ease tensions, Sir Keir is expected during the trip to finally set a date, likely 2030, for the UK to reach its goal of spending 2.5% of GDP, The Telegraph reported. This is up from the current 2.3%.

The Prime Minister will also deliver an invitation from the King for a state visit to the UK, according to the newspaper.

The US president is known to admire the royal family.

Sir Keir's trip to Washington will come after Ukraine marks three years since Russia's full-scale invasion in 2022. A defence announcement is expected to mark the occasion.

It will also come after a visit to Washington by Emmanuel Macron.

Mr Trump said Sir Keir and the French president "haven't done anything" to end the war in Ukraine in the last three years.

"They didn't do anything either (to end the war). The war's going on, no meetings with Russia, no nothing.

"They haven't done anything. Macron is a friend of mine, and I've met with the Prime Minister and he's a very nice guy (but) nobody's done anything," he told a Fox News podcast released Friday.

Mr Macron has said he intends to tell his American counterpart not to "be weak" in the face of Russian president Vladimir Putin.

Sir Keir is also facing pressure to take a firm line when he meets Mr Trump.

Liberal Democrat leader Sir Ed Davey accused Mr Trump of plotting a "stitch-up" with Mr Putin that "amounts to a betrayal of Ukraine", and urged the Prime Minister to speak "honestly and openly" with him.

Sir Ed added: "I think we're all astonished and deeply alarmed, and if the British Prime Minister doesn't reflect that, he's not reflecting the views of the British people."

But senior Cabinet minister Pat McFadden stressed the importance of maintaining a "good and constructive relationship" with the White House.

"I think the UK is potentially in a good position with this administration, if we handle it correctly.

Pat McFadden said the Government should not follow 'every twist and turn of every comment' made by Donald Trump Credit: Victoria Jones/PA

"Handling it correctly doesn't mean following every twist and turn of every comment, but is focusing on what will actually happen as well as what was said," he said at a fringe event at the Scottish Labour conference in Glasgow on Friday.

The growing rift between Mr Trump and Mr Zelensky presents a challenge for the Prime Minister.

The US leader described Mr Zelensky as a "dictator".

The Ukrainian president then claimed Mr Trump was living in a Russian "disinformation space", which led White House officials to accuse Mr Zelensky of "insulting" his counterpart.

The Americans also cancelled a planned joint press conference in Kyiv, in a sign of a deepening feud between the two countries.

Businessman Elon Musk, who is acting as an adviser on federal spending to Mr Trump, meanwhile suggested Mr Zelensky is running a "fraud machine feeding off the dead bodies of soldiers", suggesting limited appetite for continued American support for Ukraine.

However, Mr Trump's Ukraine envoy, retired general Keith Kellogg, praised Mr Zelensky on Friday as an "embattled and courageous leader of a nation at war" following what he described as "extensive and positive discussions" between the two men.

Mr Macron said he would tell Mr Trump: "It's not you, it's not your trademark, it's not in your interest.

"How can you then be credible in the face of China if you're weak in the face of Putin?"

Poland's president Andrzej Duda is set to meet Mr Trump on Saturday, Polish news agency PAP reported.

Mr Duda said he had a "candid" conversation with Mr Zelensky on Friday and urged him to "remain committed to the course of calm and constructive co-operation" with Mr Trump.

"I trust that good will and honesty form the foundation of the US negotiation strategy," he posted on X.

taxonomy_info.explanation: The article explicitly mentions Donald Trump as the US president and quotes him, confirming both the name and the description.

reasoning.presence_detection: The article explicitly references "Donald Trump" multiple times, describing him as the "US president" and referring to him as "Mr Trump" in various contexts. The description matches the target entity’s role as US President.
reasoning.statement_detection: The text contains direct quotations attributed to Donald Trump, e.g., "Mr Trump said Sir Keir and the French president 'haven't done anything'…" and a longer quote from a Fox News podcast. These are clear statements made by the entity.
reasoning.candidate_evaluation: Among the provided candidates, Q22686 is the only one whose description and occupation list include "President of the United States" and matches the target description. The other candidates (Q27947481, Q3713655, Q23000825) are unrelated professions or family members and do not align with the US President role.
reasoning.authority_verification: Q22686 holds the position of President of the United States, giving him the appropriate authority to make the statements quoted in the article.
reasoning.plausibility_assessment: It is highly plausible that the US President would comment on international relations and defence matters, as described in the article. The quoted remarks fit the typical public statements of a head of state.
reasoning.final_justification: Q22686 satisfies all critical identification and attribution criteria: name match, correct political office, and the presence of direct statements. Therefore, it is the best match for both presence verification and statement attribution.

speaker_type.explanation: The article explicitly mentions Donald Trump as the US president and quotes him, confirming both the name and the description.

classification_outcome.explanation: The article explicitly mentions Donald Trump as the US president and quotes him, confirming both the name and the description.

The name, title, and role match the Wikidata entity (French President, President of the French Republic). No conflicting information is present, confirming the entity’s presence and identity.
reasoning.statement_assessment: Macron is quoted as saying he would tell Mr. Trump: "It's not you, it's not your trademark, it's not in your interest. How can you then be credible in the face of China if you're weak in the face of Putin?" This is a clear statement attributed to him.
reasoning.plausibility_assessment: It is entirely plausible for the French president to make such remarks about the U.S. president, especially in the context of international diplomacy and defense discussions.
reasoning.contradiction_analysis: No contradictions or conflicting details regarding Macron’s identity or the statements attributed to him were found.

reasoning.presence_detection: The article explicitly mentions "White House officials" in the sentence: "...which led White House officials to accuse Mr Zelensky of 'insulting' his counterpart." This confirms the target entity is present.
reasoning.statement_detection: The phrase indicates that the White House officials made a statement (the accusation). Thus, the entity is making a declaration in the article.
reasoning.candidate_evaluation: Candidate Q1355327, "Executive Office of the President of the United States", is the only entity that represents the White House officials. The other candidate (Q130556185) is a Czech company unrelated to the U.S. White House. Therefore Q1355327 is the best match.
reasoning.authority_verification: The Executive Office of the President is the official body that houses White House officials and has the authority to issue statements on behalf of the U.S. administration.
reasoning.plausibility_assessment: It is entirely plausible for White House officials to accuse a foreign leader of insulting their counterpart, especially in the context of U.S.–Ukraine diplomatic tensions described in the article.
reasoning.final_justification: The entity "White House officials" is present and making a statement. Candidate Q1355327 aligns perfectly with the description, role, and authority required for this attribution.

input_details.name: Elon Musk
input_details.description: Businessman and adviser to Mr Trump

reasoning.identity_verification_and_presence: The article explicitly names "Businessman Elon Musk" and describes him as "acting as an adviser on federal spending to Mr Trump." This matches the Wikidata entity’s name, occupation (businessman), and the description that he is an adviser to Trump. No other individual named Elon Musk is mentioned, and the contextual details (businessman, adviser role) align with the Wikidata profile, confirming a strong identity match.
reasoning.statement_assessment: Elon Musk is directly quoted as making a statement: "suggested Mr Zelensky is running a 'fraud machine feeding off the dead bodies of soldiers'". The attribution is clear and unambiguous.
reasoning.plausibility_assessment: While Elon Musk is a well‑known entrepreneur, there is no public record of him serving as a federal spending adviser to the U.S. president. The claim that he holds such a role is unusual and not corroborated by other sources. Therefore, the plausibility of him making the statement in the capacity described is questionable, though not impossible.
reasoning.contradiction_analysis: No contradictions were found between the article’s description of Elon Musk and the Wikidata profile. The only potential issue is the unusual nature of the adviser role, which does not directly contradict the identity but raises plausibility concerns.
reasoning.confidence_level: High for identity and statement attribution; moderate for plausibility due to the atypical adviser role.

classification_outcome.explanation: The article explicitly identifies Elon Musk as a businessman and adviser to Mr. Trump and attributes a statement to him, confirming both the name and the description.

Candidate Q27916194 is an American soldier, military officer, and diplomat, with a history of high‑level security roles, matching the retired general and envoy profile. Therefore Q27916194 is the clear match.

reasoning.plausibility_assessment: It is highly plausible for a retired general serving as a Ukraine envoy to publicly praise the Ukrainian president after discussions. The attribution aligns with his role and the context of the article.
reasoning.final_justification: The entity is present in the article, making statements that are directly attributed to him. Candidate Q27916194 best matches the described profile of a retired general and Ukraine envoy, and his authority and the context support the attribution. Thus, Q27916194 is the correct Wikidata ID for both presence and statement attribution.

reasoning.statement_detection: The article attributes two statements to him: 1) "Mr Duda said he had a 'candid' conversation with Mr Zelensky on Friday and urged him to 'remain committed to the course of calm and constructive co‑operation' with Mr Trump." 2) "'I trust that good will and honesty form the foundation of the US negotiation strategy,' he posted on X." These are direct quotes and a social‑media post, indicating active statement‑making.
reasoning.candidate_evaluation: Candidate Q9151911 is a politician and lawyer who served as President of the Republic of Poland from 2015 to 2025, matching the description "Poland's president". None of the other candidates (chemistry professor, engineer, screenwriter, computer scientist) align with the political role or the context of the article. Therefore Q9151911 is the sole plausible match.
reasoning.authority_verification: Q9151911 holds the office of President of Poland, a position that confers official authority to comment on international negotiations and diplomatic relations. The statements attributed to him concern US‑Poland relations and diplomatic conduct, which are within his purview.
reasoning.plausibility_assessment: It is highly plausible for the Polish president to publicly discuss diplomatic interactions with Ukraine and the United States, and to post remarks on X about negotiation strategy. The content and medium are consistent with typical presidential communications.
reasoning.final_justification: The target entity is present in the article, making statements that are directly attributed to him. Candidate Q9151911 perfectly matches the entity’s identity, role, and the context of the statements. No other candidate fits the description or the article’s content. Therefore, Q9151911 is the correct Wikidata ID for both presence verification and statement attribution.
